Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Southeast Mariana Forearc Rifts and the Southernmost Mariana Trough Spreading Center: New Insights into the Tectonics and Magmatism of Intraoceanic Arcs
Award.AbstractNarration: Funds are provided for field work and subsequent lab study of the tectonic and magmatic evolution of an intraoceanic arc as characterized by the SE Marina Arc rifts (SEMFR) and southernmost Marina Trough spreading center. A combined deep-tow sidescan sonar and dredging/wax-coring cruise is planned to the region. The recent discovery of volcanism in the SEMFR suggests that mantle wedge asthenosphere has been drawn into the rifts and thus the PIs hope that their volcanic products may more directly reflect variations in slab fluxes and mantle melting associated with varying P-T conditions and breakdown of hydrous minerals in the underlying slab. The regional bathymetric and geophysical data synthesis will allow the PIs to kinematically model rift evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project recovered samples of lava from a unique zone where tectonic plates are being stretched above a shallow subducting plate. This is an unusual setting, because the overriding plate (i.e., the plate that stays at the surface) usually experiences compression, not extension. Lavas erupted in this region sample the mantle in the very shallow corner of the mantle, trapped between the two plates, and they also sample fluids that are explelld from the subducted plate very shallow in the system. Our findings have shown for the first time what these shallowest fluids derived from subducted plates are like. These constraints help inform models of the pressures and tempreatures of subducting plates as they descend into the mantle. Furthermore, our results show for the first time how the oxidation conditions of magmas (e.g., the availability of oxygen in magmas) respond to the effects of crystallization and degassing. This result is important because magmatic redox influences what volatile gases a magma may emit when it erupts, and how Earth’s crustal structure and composition change in response to the conditions of magmas. When volcanoes erupt, the composition of volcanic gases expelled into the atmosphere is controlled by the oxidation conditions. For example, whether a volcano emits H2S or SO2 gas has an impact on the sulfate content of the atmosphere, which ultimately may impact global temperatures. The oxidation conditions of magmas may also control how and when the Earth makes continental crust, on which we live. The explosivity of volcanic systems, as controlled by the dissolved volatile content of magmas, also impacts human populations living near volcanoes, as well as global air traffic.
